page.title: 02ECOLOGY,SOUTH CREAKE
page.content: The climate, and the nature of the soil, have been major factors in the development of the village, Hard winters, prevailing East winds, low rainfall, and light soil, have combined to produce an arable economy. The effect of the removal of hedges adjoining roads, has been an increase in the chances of the village being cut off by drifting snow. For some years a conservation area, the worst effects of development are being controlled. Pollution is not a problem, except for straw and stubble burning. However, trout in the River Burn were killed by accidental spillage of agricultural chemicals in 1984. Footpaths have gone; of more concern to ramblers than to inhabitants; their original purpose of passage to church and school, being no longer required.
